Hi,
	So, from this and your previous message, do I correctly deduce that the 
averaging part of the fitness function has worked?

	e.g. (if I remember your plan correctly) you supply top-left and 
bottom-right coords for a rectangular area of the 9x9 input image, and you 
have produced a network which correctly answers with the average of that 
part of the image.

	If this is so, then that alone is very interesting, because to do that you 
must have achieved some sort of 2D multiplexor (addressing circuitry) in 
your networks.  Even a 1D multiplexor is very interesting (e.g. a network 
which, given one input between 0 and 1, selects one of N other inputs as 
the output [N being fixed and moderately large]).  A 2D multiplexor can be 
built from N+1 1D multiplexors...

	If, as I am just starting to suspect, you were just referring to one of 
your averaging tests (was (1,1) - (9,9) the first test applied) then I 
think you may have a point about the construction of your fitness 
function.  It may be that the step between your first and second fitness 
terms is too high.  Wasn't the first one average for the whole thing, needs 
no multiplexors and the second dome other average which does need 
multiplexing?  The system cannot evolve up one of these "cliffs" unless 
there are reasonably spaced steps all the way.  If your second term cannot 
start giving a reward at all until after some multiplexor is achieved, then 
that's probably too high a probability barrier.  Maybe if your second 
fitness term involved only a lower limit and only on one axis and only 
between two ordinate values (e.g if it required distinguishing (1,1) - 
(9,9) and (5,1) - (9,9)).  Then your third step could do the same thing on 
the other axis....

	Ian Badcoe
